head.title: Antiferromagnetic Order of the Ru and Gd in Superconducting RuSr_2GdCu_2O_8

article.h1: Antiferromagnetic Order of the Ru and Gd in Superconducting RuSr22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}GdCu22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O88FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{8}

span.span: J. W. Lynn11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}, B. Keimer22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, C. Ulrich1,212FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1,2}, C. Bernhard22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, and J. L. Tallon33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3}

11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}NIST Center for Neutron Research, National Institute of
Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland 20899 USA
22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}Max-Planck Institute für Festkörperforschung,
Heisenbergstrasse 1, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany
33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3}Industrial Research Ltd., P. O. Box 31310, Lower Hutt, New Zealand

div.p: Neutron diffraction has been used to study the magnetic order in RuSr22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}GdCu22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O88FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{8}. The Ru moments order antiferromagnetically at TN=136⁢(2)⁢Ksubscript𝑇𝑁1362𝐾italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:136 OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-KT_{N}=136(2)K, coincident with the previously reported onset of ferromagnetism. Neighboring spins are antiparallel in all three directions, with a low T moment of 1.18(6) μBsubscript𝜇𝐵italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B} along the c axis. Our measurements put an upper limit of ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim0.1 μBsubscript𝜇𝐵italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B} to any net zero-field moment, with fields exceeding 0.4⁢T0.4𝑇NUMBER:0.4 italic-T0.4T needed to induce a measurable magnetization. The Gd ions order independently at TN=2.50⁢(2)⁢Ksubscript𝑇𝑁2.502𝐾italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.50 OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-KT_{N}=2.50(2)K with the same spin configuration.

The ruthenate class of materials has been the focus of considerable work recently because of their interesting magnetic and superconducting properties. SrRuO33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}, for example, is a 4d band ferromagnet that orders at 165 K,[1] while Sr22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}RuO44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4} is an exotic p-wave superconductor (TC=1.5⁢Ksubscript𝑇𝐶1.5𝐾italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.5 italic-KT_{C}=1.5K).[2] Of particular interest here is the recent report of ferromagnetic ordering of the Ru at 133 K in RuSr22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}GdCu22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O88FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{8}, while bulk superconductivity is established at lower temperatures as observed in susceptibility and specific heat.[3, 4] In these hybrid ruthenate-cuprate systems both the Cu-O and Ru-O planes form very similar square-planar arrays, and the coexistence of superconductivity and long range magnetic order at high temperatures is intriguing.[5] Previous “magnetic-superconductors” such as the Chevrel phases (R⁢M⁢o6⁢S8𝑅𝑀subscript𝑜6subscript𝑆8italic-R italic-M italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endRMo_{6}S_{8}, R𝑅italic-RR = rare earth ion),[6] borocarbides (R⁢N⁢i2⁢B2⁢C𝑅𝑁subscript𝑖2subscript𝐵2𝐶italic-R italic-N italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-CRNi_{2}B_{2}C),[7] and cuprates (R⁢B⁢a2⁢C⁢u3⁢O7𝑅𝐵subscript𝑎2𝐶subscript𝑢3subscript𝑂7italic-R italic-B italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-C italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endRBa_{2}Cu_{3}O_{7} and related materials)[8] show rare earth ordering at low temperature (≲10⁢Kless-than-or-similar-toabsent10𝐾RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:10 italic-K\lesssim 10K ), and almost all are antiferromagnets that do not couple strongly to the superconductivity. The rare occurrence of ferromagnetism,[6] as found in E⁢r⁢R⁢h4⁢B4𝐸𝑟𝑅subscriptℎ4subscript𝐵4italic-E italic-r italic-R italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endErRh_{4}B_{4}, H⁢o⁢M⁢o6⁢S8𝐻𝑜𝑀subscript𝑜6subscript𝑆8italic-H italic-o italic-M italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endHoMo_{6}S_{8}, and H⁢o⁢M⁢o6⁢S⁢e8𝐻𝑜𝑀subscript𝑜6𝑆subscript𝑒8italic-H italic-o italic-M italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endHoMo_{6}Se_{8}, revealed the strongly competitive nature of these two cooperative phenomena in the form of long wavelength oscillatory magnetic states at low temperature (≲1⁢Kless-than-or-similar-toabsent1𝐾RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:1 italic-K\lesssim 1K) and a ferromagnetic lock-in transition that quenches the superconductivity.[9, 10, 11] It would then be quite interesting if RuSr22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}GdCu22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O88FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{8} were a ferromagnetic superconductor with such a high magnetic ordering temperature, as this would suggest[12] a superconducting order parameter of the Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov type[13] that could exhibit π𝜋italic-pi\pi-phase behavior.[14] Our diffraction results, however, demonstrate that the magnetic order of the Ru is predominantly antiferromagnetic, instead making this by far the highest known antiferromagnetic ordering to coexist with superconductivity. An upper limit of ∼0.1⁢μBsimilar-toabsent0.1subscript𝜇𝐵RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.1 italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim 0.1\mu_{B} is obtained for the ferromagnetic component, consistent with recent magnetization data, and the system is then similar to E⁢r⁢N⁢i2⁢B2⁢C𝐸𝑟𝑁subscript𝑖2subscript𝐵2𝐶italic-E italic-r italic-N italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-CErNi_{2}B_{2}C, where a net magnetization develops below 2.3 K.[15] The Gd moments also order magnetically, but at low temperatures in a manner analogous to previous magnetic-superconductor systems.

A polycrystalline sample of RuSr22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}GdCu22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}O88FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{8} was prepared by the solid state reaction technique, using the 160160FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:160 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{160}Gd isotope to avoid the huge nuclear absorption cross section of natural Gd. The single-phase sample weighed ∼1.5similar-toabsent1.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1.5\sim 1.5 g, has an onset superconducting temperature of 35 K and bulk superconducting TC𝐶FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{C} of 21 K, and is the identical sample used in a previous susceptibility and neutron crystallographic study.[16] All the present neutron data were collected at NIST. BT-2 was employed at a neutron wavelength of 2.359 Å, with a pyrolytic graphite filter to suppress higher-order wavelengths. Polarized neutron measurements were carried out with a Heusler monochromator and analyzer. A 33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3}He refrigerator was employed for the lowest temperature measurements, and a vertical field 7T superconducting magnet for the field measurements. Small angle neutron scattering data were also collected with a wavelength of 5Å on the NG-1 spectrometer from 6K to 300K. Statistical uncertainties quoted in this article represent one standard deviation.

Fig. 1 shows a portion of the diffraction pattern obtained at a temperature of 16 K. The peak at 23.5∘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{{}^{\circ}} is the weak {002} nuclear Bragg peak; for comparison, the strong {103}+{110} Bragg peak at 51.5∘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{{}^{\circ}} has 4809 counts/min. The peaks at 25.8∘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{{}^{\circ}} and 30.8∘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{{}^{\circ}} can be indexed as the {12,12,12}121212OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}\} and {12,12,32}121232OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{3}{2}\} reflections. At a temperature of 150 K we see that these peaks have completely disappeared, indicating that they are magnetic and originate from the magnetic ordering of the Ru. There is no change in the nuclear Bragg intensity, where a ferromagnetic component would appear, as clearly indicated by the difference scattering[17] shown at the bottom of the figure. The temperature dependence of the integrated intensity for the {12,12,12}121212OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}\} peak is shown in Fig. 2. The solid curve is a simple mean field fit to estimate a Néel temperature of 136(2) K. This is in excellent agreement with the reported Ru magnetic ordering temperature.[3]

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: Portion of a diffraction pattern at 16K, showing the weak nuclear {002} powder peak along with the {12,12,12}121212OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}\}and {12,12,32}121232OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{3}{2}\} Ru antiferromagnetic Bragg peaks. At 150 K the two magnetic peaks have disappeared, while there is no change in the {002} peak, where a ferromagnetic component would be observed. The difference scattering obtained by subtracting the two data sets is shown at the bottom.

div.p: The data in Fig. 1 show that the Ru moments order antiferromagnetically, with nearest neighbor spins in all three crystallographic directions aligned antiparallel. The magnetic scattering for a collinear structure is[18]

semantics.annotation: italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-C VERTBAR:| italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-k italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-k italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start TRIGFUNCTION:sine OPEN:( italic-theta CLOSE:) TRIGFUNCTION:sine OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-theta CLOSE:) ARG:end OPEN:langle NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus OPEN:( OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-tau ARG:end MULOP:cdot OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-M ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle

div.p: where C𝐶italic-CC is an instrumental constant, mh⁢k⁢lsubscript𝑚ℎ𝑘𝑙italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-k italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{hkl} is the multiplicity of the powder peak with Miller indices h⁢k⁢lℎ𝑘𝑙italic-h italic-k italic-lhkl for the reciprocal lattice vector τ𝜏italic-tau{\bf\tau}, Ah⁢k⁢lsubscript𝐴ℎ𝑘𝑙italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-k italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{hkl} is the absorption factor, M^^𝑀OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-M ARG:end\widehat{M} is a unit vector in the direction of the moment, and the brackets indicate a powder/domain average. The magnetic structure factor is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:langle italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-tau CLOSE:) italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-tau MULOP:cdot bold-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: where ⟨μjz⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑗𝑧OPEN:langle italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle\left\langle\mu_{j}^{z}\right\rangle is the ordered moment and fj⁢(h⁢k⁢l)subscript𝑓𝑗ℎ𝑘𝑙italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-h italic-k italic-l CLOSE:)f_{j}(hkl) is the magnetic form factor for the jt⁢hsuperscript𝑗𝑡ℎitalic-j POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endj^{th} ion at position 𝐫jsubscript𝐫𝑗bold-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf r}_{j} in the unit cell, Wj𝑗FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{j} is the Debye-Waller factor, and the sum is over all atoms in the unit cell. The magnetic intensities can be put on an absolute scale by comparison with the nuclear intensities. The intensity for the {12,12,32}121232OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{3}{2}\} peak in Fig. 1 is clearly reduced in intensity compared to the {12,12,12}121212OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}\} peak, and the orientation factor in Eq. (1) then suggests that the direction of the moment is along the tetragonal c axis. The observed intensity ratio of the {12,12,12}121212OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}\} to {12,12,32}121232OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{3}{2}\} peaks is 2.49(40), which is indeed in good agreement with the calculated value of 2.21. Of course, with only two observable magnetic peaks this moment direction assignment is tentative rather than definitive. The ordered Ru moment at low temperatures is then 1.18(6) μBsubscript𝜇𝐵italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B}, which agrees nicely with the moment of 1.05(5) μBsubscript𝜇𝐵italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B} obtained from susceptibility.[3]

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: Integrated intensity of the {12,12,12}121212OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}\} Ru magnetic Bragg peak vs. T. The curve is a fit to mean-field theory.

div.p: Any ferromagnetic contribution to the scattering will occur at the same positions as the nuclear Bragg peaks, and the data in Fig. 1 indicate no magnetic contribution to the {002} peak within experimental error. We measured the intensities of the ten lowest-angle nuclear Bragg reflections above and below the Ru magnetic ordering temperature, and these data provide an upper limit of ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim0.1 μBsubscript𝜇𝐵italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B} to any ferromagnetic component. This result was substantiated by polarized beam measurements, although the error limit was comparable to that obtained with unpolarized neutrons. We also monitored the flipping ratio of the intensity transmitted through the sample to determine if there were any depolarization of the beam as might be expected for a ferromagnet. No change with temperature was observed. Finally, we measured the small angle scattering on NG-1 in an attempt to see any critical scattering associated with ferromagnetic correlations that might develop, but no scattering was observed. Therefore the neutron data so far do not reveal the ferromagnetic component associated with the Ru ordering.

The field dependence of the magnetic scattering of the {12,12,12}121212OPEN:{ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PUNCT:, FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:}\{\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}\} and {002}002OPEN:{ NUMBER:002 CLOSE:}\{002\} peaks, corresponding to the antiferromagnetic order and induced ferromagnetic moment, respectively, is shown in Fig. 3. A temperature of 80 K was chosen for these measurements since this is well below the Ru ordering temperature so that the sublattice magnetization is near its saturated value, but it is high enough in temperature that the Gd paramagnetic moment should not dominate the net magnetization except at the highest fields. No significant change in either intensity is observed up to ∼0.4⁢Tsimilar-toabsent0.4𝑇RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4 italic-T\sim 0.4T. With further increase of field the intensity of the antiferromagnetic reflection begins to decrease, while the induced magnetization increases. At the highest field of 7⁢T7𝑇NUMBER:7 italic-T7T there is no significant antiferromagnetic intensity remaining (as indicated by full angular scans), while the induced magnetization corresponds to a net moment of 1.4(1) μBsubscript𝜇𝐵italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B} perpendicular to c. The calculated induced Gd paramagnetic moment is shown by the dashed curve, and for fields above ∼0.4⁢Tsimilar-toabsent0.4𝑇RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4 italic-T\sim 0.4T the data systematically lie above the curve indicating a Ru contribution. However, the value is ∼0.2similar-toabsent0.2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2\sim 0.2 μBsubscript𝜇𝐵italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B}, which suggests the Ru moments are rotating into another antiferromagnetic (spin-flop) structure, rather than becoming fully aligned with the field. Returning to zero field, all the peaks recover their zero-field intensities, indicating that the effect of the field is reversible, and also that no preferred orientation of the loose powder particles occurred when the field was applied. The Gd anisotropy is very small since it is an S-state ion. The low spin-flop field and the lack of any field-induced preferred orientation then suggests that the Ru crystalline anisotropy is also relatively weak, indicating that a Heisenberg Hamiltonian is appropriate to describe the Ru spin system.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: Field dependence of the square of the antiferromagnetic moment and induced ferromagnetic moment (∝proportional-toRELOP:proportional-to\propto normalized observed intensity) at 80 K. An expanded scale has been used at low fields for clarity. The dashed curve represents the induced Gd moment.
Figure 4: Magnetic diffraction pattern for Gd, obtained by subtracting the data at 1.6 K from the data at 5K.

div.p: We now turn to measurements of the Gd magnetic order. Fig. 4 shows the magnetic diffraction pattern, obtained by subtracting the data at 5 K from the data at 1.6 K, below TN𝑁FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{N}.[17] We see that the peak positions and relative intensities are identical to that for the Ru, so that nearest-neighbor Gd spins are also coupled antiferromagnetically along all three crystallographic directions, with the moment direction along the tetragonal c axis. The calculated and observed intensities then agree to within the statistical uncertainties.

figure.figcaption: Figure 5: Gd sublattice magnetization vs. T. The Néel temperature is 2.50 K. The inset shows the magnetic structures for the Ru and Gd.

div.p: The temperature dependence of the sublattice magnetization for the Gd is shown in Fig. 5. We obtain the expected 7 μBsubscript𝜇𝐵italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{B} moment within experimental uncertainties at low T. Near TN𝑁FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{N} a small correction has been applied to the observed intensity to account for critical scattering, and the solid curve is a fit to a modified power law, with a fitted ordering temperature of 2.50(2) K. The sharpness of the ordering might at first be surprising since the Ru and Gd magnetic structures are identical, and hence one might expect them to be strongly coupled, smearing the Gd order parameter. However, the Gd ions sit at the body-centered position of the simple tetragonal Ru lattice. The antiferromagnetic magnetic structure for the Ru then results in a cancellation of the average interaction between the Gd and Ru (Fig. 4), rendering the two spin systems fully frustrated (neglecting quantum fluctuations) with respect to each other and thus behaving independently to a good approximation. It is noteworthy that this frustration is relieved by a (zero-field) ferromagnetic component on the Ru sublattice, so that the sharpness of the Gd order parameter is another indication that the Ru magnetic structure can have only a modest net moment.

The Ru antiferromagnetic moment we observe is in good agreement with the moment obtained from susceptibility, accounting for essentially the full ordered moment. Our experimental upper limit of ∼0.1⁢μBsimilar-toabsent0.1subscript𝜇𝐵RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.1 italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim 0.1\mu_{B} on the ferromagnetic component is consistent with the spontaneous moment derived from low-field data, but is inconsistent with band structure calculations predicting full ferromagnetic spin polarization of the Ru subsystem.[12] The crystallographic data[16, 4] indicate a rotation of the RuO66FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{6} octahedra about the c-axis, with a small rotation around an axis perpendicular to c. It is the latter rotation that would be needed for conventional mechanisms such as antisymmetric exchange or single-ion anisotropy to produce a canting and net Ru moment as observed in a variety of measurements.[3, 4] In any case, the antiferromagnetism is dominant, and the coexistence of superconductivity with the high ordering temperature and consequent large exchange interactions of the Ru make this an especially interesting system for further investigations.
Acknowledgments. We would like to thank R.W. Erwin and Q. Huang for their assistance, and J. D. Jorgensen for communicating their results prior to publication.
